issues.description: Attribute type mismatch for Ride.abbreviation: the UML in the problem statement declares Ride.abbreviation as String, but the solution implementation declares it as char. This divergence means students implementing the UML-specified String type will produce a different class API than the provided solution, leading to signature/test mismatches and confusion about the intended type.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the type of 'abbreviation' consistent across artifacts. Either update the UML/problem statement to specify 'abbreviation: char' (if a single character is intended), or change the solution (and template) to use String for 'abbreviation' and update all constructors/getters accordingly. Ensure the template, problem text, and solution all use the same type.

issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch caused by inconsistent 'abbreviation' type: the problem requires public constructors matching the UML attribute types and order, but the solution constructors take a char for abbreviation while the UML specifies abbreviation as String. This affects the Ride constructor and all subclasses' constructors (RollerCoaster, LaunchedRollerCoaster, LaunchedDropdownTower), producing inconsistent constructor signatures versus the UML/specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Align constructor parameter types with the chosen 'abbreviation' type across all artifacts. If 'abbreviation' should be String per UML, change the constructors in the solution and template to accept String (and update attribute types and getters). If a char is intended, update the UML/problem statement to list 'abbreviation: char' and explicitly mention this in the task description so students implement constructors with char parameters.
